Counsel: Gilleece & Gilleece, White Plains (Kevin P. Gilleece of counsel), and Lanna & Coppola, Yonkers, for 
Alfred "Nick" Rattenni and others, appellants.  I. To the prejudice of defendants, the Grand Jury was never 
instructed to apply the "rule of reason" to the dealings between the parties but was instructed that any allocation of 
customers was per se illegal and could not have a business justification.  ( Business Elecs. Corp. v Sharp  [****2]   
Elecs., 485 US 717; National Socy. of Professional Engrs. v United States, 435 US 679; National Coll. Athletic 
Assn. v Board of Regents, 468 US 84; Federal Trade Commn. v Indiana Fedn. of Dentists, 476 US 447; United 
States v Portsmouth Paving Corp., 694 F2d 312; United States v Suntar Roofing, 897 F2d 469; United States v 
Cooperative Theatres, 845 F2d 1367; Baker's Aid v Hussmann Foodservice Co., 730 F Supp 1209; Anheuser-
Busch, Inc. v Abrams, 71 NY2d 327.) II. The evidence presented to the Grand Jury was legally insufficient.  ( 
People v Jennings, 69 NY2d 103; People v Mikuszewski, 73 NY2d 407; Anheuser-Busch, Inc. v Abrams, 71 NY2d 
327.) 
B. Anthony Morosco, White Plains, and James M. Rose for Frank Giannattasio, Jr., and others, appellants.  The 
People charged the Grand Jury to consider the agreement between the parties as a per se violation of the Donnelly 
Act, despite the fact that the Grand Jury should have considered the facts before it and applied the "rule of reason" 
in which case it would have found the evidence was insufficient.  ( National Socy of Professional Engrs. v United 
States, 435 US 679;  [****3]  United States v Koppers Co., 652 F2d 290; United States v Suntar Roofing, 897 F2d 
469; Pennsylvania Dental Assn. v Medical Serv. Assn., 745 F2d 248, 471 US 1016; Northern Pac. Ry. Co. v United 
States, 356 US 1; Standard Oil Co. v United States, 221 US 1; Atkin v Union Processing Corp., 90 AD2d 332; 59 
NY2d 919, 465 US 1038; Baker's Aid v Hussmann Foodservice Co., 730 F Supp 1209; Meteor Indus. v Metalloy 
Indus., 149 AD2d 483; Purchasing Assocs. v Weitz, 13 NY2d 267.) 
81 N.Y.2d 166, *166; 613 N.E.2d 155, **155; 597 N.Y.S.2d 280, ***280; 1993 N.Y. LEXIS 659, ****1

 
Robert Abrams, Attorney-General, New York City (Gary J. Malone, George Sampson, Jerry Boone and Joseph 
Opper of counsel), for respondent.  I. An agreement among competitors to allocate customers, such as the 
agreement charged in the indictment, is a per se violation of the Donnelly Act.  ( Anheuser-Busch, Inc. v Abrams, 71 
NY2d 327; State of New York v Mobile Oil Corp., 38 NY2d 460; National Socy of Professional Engrs. v United 
States, 435 US 679; United States v Topco Assocs., 405 US 596; Palmer v BRG of Ga., 498 US 46; United States 
v Suntar Roofing, 897 F2d 469; United States v Cooperative Theatres, 845 F2d 1367; United  [****4]   States v 
Cadillac Overall Supply Co., 568 F2d 1078; United States v Consolidated Laundries Corp., 291 F2d 563; United 
States v Goodman, 850 F2d 1473.) II. The evidence before the Grand Jury was legally sufficient to sustain the 
indictment.  ( People v Warner-Lambert Co., 51 NY2d 295, 450 US 1031; People v Jennings, 69 NY2d 103; People 
v Mikuszewski, 73 NY2d 407.)
